key_title: Key to the species of Spyridium

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Spyridium
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1999). Spyridium. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves entire or if ever emarginate, at least some longer than 12 mm
Leaf tips toothed, notched or deeply cleft, no longer than 12 mm; rare shrubs of Little Desert, Grampians or East Gippsland
Leaves deeply cleft, Y-shaped; margins strongly recurved; normal leaves glabrescent on upper surface; southern fringes of Little Desert
Leaves obovate, 3-toothed at apex; margins plane to slightly recurved; leaves all greyish-pubescent above and below; Grampians and East Gippsland heaths
Leaves glabrous or pubescent, but not with shining appressed hairs
Surfaces of leaves shining from a covering of appressed silky hairs; rare, spindly shrub of southern Big Desert near South Australian border
Floral leaves white-felted, differing from stem leaves
Floral leaves not noticeably differing from stem leaves
Leaves with lateral veins impressed above and with prominent lateral venation; upper surfaces (other than floral leaves) glabrous or hispid
Leaves with lateral venation indistinct, not impressed above; upper surface (other than floral leaves) glabrous; shrub of western heaths
Leaves narrow-elliptic, at least twice as long as wide; Grampians only
Leaves broadly ovate to broadly obovate, less than twice as long as wide; widespread shrub, including Grampians
Leaves linear, sharp-pointed or mucronate, glabrous; margins revolute, under-surface not or barely visible

Leaves oblong or narrowly ovate to narrowly obovate, obtuse, at least when young usually greyish from a covering of fine stellate hairs; margins recurved to revolute, but undersurface usually partly exposed
Stipules obtuse to acute but lacking fine-acuminate apices; flowers virtually sessile in dense, button-like heads
Stipules with fine-acuminate apices; flowers distinctly pedicellate, in subumbellate cymes; Grampians only
